body: Psalm doesn't understand version-conditional code. Mind creating a minimal reproducer in a separate repo? I'd like to try to implement this.

Here you go https://github.com/simonberger/psalmbug

Very minimal. There is no project file needed for it to fail
Why is this file read without any reference. Not even to the package.

functions are a special case in composer, they're loaded automatically in global scope. You must have a dependancy that needs the polyfill, which means composer have to load the functions for your dependancy
We are still looking at a project with zero files to analyze which (in theory) means zero dependencies. Obviously something triggers psalm to read it I don't know its internals to make guesses.

`<ignoreFiles><directory name="vendor" /></ignoreFiles>` doesn't work in this case. I tried add ignore directly `<ignoreFiles><file name="vendor/symfony/polyfill-mbstring/bootstrap80.php"</ignoreFiles>`, but it doesn't work too. Someone tried fix this issue in `symfony/polyfill-mbstring`, but looks like problem is `vimeo/psalm` site. https://github.com/symfony/polyfill/pull/327

> `<ignoreFiles><directory name="vendor" /></ignoreFiles>` doesn't work in this case. I tried add ignore directly `<ignoreFiles><file name="vendor/symfony/polyfill-mbstring/bootstrap80.php"</ignoreFiles>`, but it doesn't work too. Someone tried fix this issue in `symfony/polyfill-mbstring`, but looks like problem is `vimeo/psalm` site. [symfony/polyfill#327](https://github.com/symfony/polyfill/pull/327)

I also think symfony-polyfill is totally fine.

issue.title: ParseError - vendor/symfony/polyfill-mbstring/bootstrap80.php:125:86

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
While scanning ../../mod/checklist weird Error from vendor/symfony folder is popping out.
Why this is happening, although I ignore vendor files in psalm-plugin.xml?

```xml
<projectFiles>
    <ignoreFiles>
        <directory name="vendor"/>
        <file name="psalm-autoload.php"/>
    </ignoreFiles>
</projectFiles>
``` 

```console
./vendor/bin/psalm --config=psalm-plugin.xml --show-info=true --no-diff ../../mod/checklist
Scanning files...
Analyzing files...

░░░░░░I░░░░░░░░░░░░░░░I░░░░░░░░░░░░░░I░░░░░░

ERROR: ParseError - vendor/symfony/polyfill-mbstring/bootstrap80.php:125:86 - Syntax error, unexpected '=' on line 125 (see https://psalm.dev/173)
    function mb_scrub(string $string, string $encoding = null): string { $encoding ??= mb_internal_encoding(); return mb_convert_encoding($string, $encoding, $encoding); }


INFO: PossibleSqlInjection - ../../mod/checklist/autoupdate.php:107:24 - Calling unsafe sql method $DB->get_records_sql
SQL:
    SELECT i.id AS itemid, i.checklist, cl.teacheredit, ck.*, cl.course
              FROM {checklist_item} i
              JOIN {checklist} cl ON i.checklist = cl.id
              LEFT JOIN {checklist_check} ck ON (ck.item = i.id AND ck.userid = :userid)
             WHERE cl.autoupdate > 0 AND i.moduleid = :cmid AND i.itemoptional < :heading
Documentation -
    $itemchecks = $DB->get_records_sql($sql, ['userid' => $userid, 'cmid' => $cmid, 'heading' => CHECKLIST_OPTIONAL_HEADING]);
```

body:
I have same problem.
I want to add that it doesn't happend every time I run Psalm with ` --no-diff `.

> Obviously something triggers psalm to read

I think it just parses everything in `vendor` before looking into your code? e.g. see `psalm --debug`

And yeah, we have the same issue in a PHP 7.2+ project  :)
I'm going to propose a PR that would avoid scanning files that are conditionally included based on `PHP_VERSION_ID` (as is the case with multiple symfony polyfills).

issue.title: Probelm parsing psalm.xml ParseError is not expected

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
Getting this error by running `./vendor/bin/psalm`

```
Problem parsing <path>/psalm.xml:
  Error on line 84:
    Element '{https://getpsalm.org/schema/config}ParseError': This element is not expected.
```

I see in the doc [Issue.md](https://github.com/vimeo/psalm/blob/master/docs/issues.md#parseerror) that a `ParseError` element exists.

issue.title: Skip conditional includes when registering autoload files

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
This should allow analysis of forward-compatible polyfills used in codebases targeting older PHP versions.

The following previously problematic polyfills should now emit no parse errors:

* `symfony/polyfill-ctype`
* `symfony/polyfill-intl-grapheme`
* `symfony/polyfill-intl-normalizer`
* `symfony/polyfill-mbstring`

The pattern that is now works as intended looks like this:
```php
if (\PHP_VERSION_ID >= 80000) {
    require __DIR__ . '/bootstrap80.php';
    return;
}
```

Previously Psalm would scan the required file even when the codebase targeted older PHP versions, and would emit parse errors when that file contained PHP 8 syntax.

Fixes #4961 and #4965

body:
> would it also be possible to add a config option to scope files to minimum PHP versions?

Can you elaborate?

> There are definitely other different ways of doing this

With #4967 I'm not aiming to fix all possible cases, just those common enough that people reported them. Symfony polyfills are certainly common, and they use `PHP_VERSION_ID`. It can be extended later when other patterns surface being used in the wild.

> Can you elaborate?

Something like this:

```xml
<projectFiles>
    <directory name="app"/>
    <ignoreFiles>
        <file name="./vendor/symfony/polyfill-mbstring/bootstrap80.php" min-version="8.0" />
    </ignoreFiles>
</projectFiles>
```

or maybe something like:

```xml
<projectFiles>
    <directory name="app"/>
    <ignoreFiles>
        <php min-version="8.0">
             <file name="./vendor/symfony/polyfill-mbstring/bootstrap80.php" />
        </php>
    </ignoreFiles>
</projectFiles>
```
That wouldn't be necessary, as those files would be omitted when scanning based on actual conditions of the `if` statements they are wrapped into.

Would psalm parse the file if it were named bootstrap.php8?
That's a change I'd be ok to do if yes.

issue.title: Use null-coalesce instead of null-coalesce-equals
issue.body:
The use of the PHP 8.0 only null-coalesce-equals (`??=`) means that this file causes Psalm to see it as a parse error for projects not yet migrated to PHP 8. There is currently no way to avoid this, as psalm considers a parse error an unignorable error, even though in this case the file would never be included unless it actually is running on PHP 8.0.

The only way to avoid this is to set the entire project as PHP 8.0 but then you wouldn't be notified of legitimate issues when deploying to PHP 7.x.

It's a simple change from `$a ??= $b` to `$a = $a ?? $b` form.

body:
> Would psalm parse the file if it were named bootstrap.php8?

It would still parse the file.
